review_title: Do not Join Honeywell HBT / HBS / BMS
pros:
1. Good direct managers, but unfortunately all are controlled by SG higher management by fear, and he will not be leaving anytime soon.

2. I really cannot think of any apart from the standard benefits (annual leaves, medical claims) that almost every company is offering, if not more.
cons:
I am a current employee from the dept of HBS/HBT, working on BMS/Fire system. OP from Labour Day'21 mentioned alot of facts.

Higher management "forced" everyone to sign a "voluntary unpaid leave e-form". Something what I have never imagined would happened in a MNC. Why want to implement the forced "voluntary unpaid leave e-form"? Highly likely because he already knew it was against the SG law to forced employees to take unpaid leaves, and that form was meant to protect himself in case someone whistleblow and MOM checks. And yet he still went ahead with it. Called it voluntary but said that a list of names of who signed/have no signed will be sent to himself. Why these actions if it is meant to be voluntary??

Maybe desperate to cut cost too for Covid-19, but as someone receiving a high pay/month, using this kind of method just meant he does not have the capabilities to come up with other solutions and unfit to be in that position. Paid highly to solve the issue but chose a solution that goes against the law.

Labour Day'21 has mentioned alot but not everything. It is just the tip of the iceberg. Not sure about other dept but if u join as a engineer (regardless of title name), you will be wasting your time doing mindless stuff out of your jobscope and learning nothing ! Eg: Go to customer office to collect payment cheque, deliver back to office and end up with no time to do other work, only to be criticized for not managing time properly.

Honeywell squeeze engineers dry and engineers does everything. Admin, sales, finance, budgeting, etc.

review_title: We get things done. We only get things done.
pros:
- Good learning opportunity. Exposure to projects of different natures.

- Supportive first-line managers. The managers work with the engineers to get things done. The managers are in general very capable, and are armed with the necessary skills and knowledge.

- Supportive colleagues. There's a good culture of colleagues helping each other. Most of the time, initiatives were taken to reach out to colleagues in trouble.

- Plenty of capable and dedicated engineers.

- Pay is above the market rate (but for a reason...)
cons:
- We were always in a rush to get things out. In a way, the short time span for products/fixes to be released to the market is good for the business, but it's not healthy from the engineering standpoint. We were not given enough time to research extensively and think things through.

- Workload could be heavy, to the point that personal time was sacrificed. 

- There was also an unbalanced allocation of workload. Capable engineers were loaded more heavily.

- The engineers were working on all sorts of different projects, as long as they were related to their fields. Specialisation was not emphasised, and this might result in they becoming 'generalists' rather than 'specialists'. This is limiting the engineers' growth and the quality of their work.

review_title: Questionable Leadership in HR Admin Manila Hub
pros: High basic salary but other than that the benefits package is not even at par with the current benefits package that the other competitors are offering
cons:
Questionable leadership skills of the Leadership team in Manila Hub. Poor recruitment skills that resulted to unfit people being put in different roles, heavily influenced by politics since people tends to recruit their colleagues from previous company, unfair and demotivating recognition practices without clear basis. Inconsistency is also a factor since rules only applied to some people and not for all. No employee handbook existing but they will implement rules whenever needed without clear understanding from the employees side.The contract that you signed tends to change from time to time, Example- You signed up to follow Philippine Holidays but you will be asked to report on PH holidays anyway. Benefits package is also very low compared to other Shared Services in the Philippines. They do not have HMO. SL is not convertible.

They try to stop people by leaving by means of blindly promoting anyone they can’t afford to loose even if they are not capable for the job.

review_title: Highest Paid CEO and Stellar Earnings at the expense of Employees
pros:
- A good place to acquire Aerospace product knowledge for fresh graduates 
- Emphasis on Lean and Six Sigma has been effective in making the site produce more with less.
cons:
- Repeatedly impose pay freeze and furloughs to make the earnings look good despite the company not making any losses. Rank and file employees feel the pinch with pay cuts while the senior management in Phoenix and Morristown enjoy the fruits of higher value of their stock options. Rewarding senior management not for adding value but for a zero-sum game where the company wins and the employee loses
- Extremely short sighted and can’t see beyond meeting the sales and shipment target of the month. No willingness to invest in new machines because they depreciate fast and is a drag on earnings. The plant is forced to squeeze whatever juice remaining of the old equipments which are less efficient
- Paltry employee benefits. All benefits removed due to cost reductions were not reinstated when the good times return
- No career planning for rank and file employees. Almost zero chance of organic promotion.
- Lean and Six Sigma focus means extra work for employees without headcount increase

job_title: Solutions Architect in Bukit Batok New Town,
pros:
To contribute in supply chain workflow solutions. 
Bring innovations in inbound to outbound workflow processes.
Increase accuracy and productivity in operations.
At least 50% cost savings in labour.
cons:
Need to manage reporting managers and external partners and expected to fill all gaps.
Lacks the opportunity to manage lateral partners as the reporting manager is too micro managing and wants detail level of work in progress.
Too many team meeting i.e. In one week, meet at least 2-3 times for work progress update.
Repetitive timesheet broken down into must do list, need to do list and nice to do list. Absolute redundant activity as all these tasks listed will be tracked as to do, like it or not.
Absolute indicator again of micro management by the reporting manager.

job_title: Advanced Electrical Design Engineer in Brno
pros: - Relatively high salary in the area - Well-equipped labs, and high-tech development environment - Daily contact with English-speaking colleagues - Time-to-time travel opportunities - International environment - I would say it is good for graduates
cons: - No clear vision from management for a particular business - They often let you work on some project which is later canceled - Strong feeling of useless work - Really strong bureaucracy and overprocessing for everything - You wait for ages for a clear decision approval etc. - Lots of corporate bu***t emails, meetings, reports, etc. (no time for work) - Long-term employees are often burnt out and resigned (including me after 10+ years) - Terrible IT infrastructure. They block a lot of things (including web pages that are not on the whitelist). When you need support, you can barely contact any person directly. First you need to try to solve via chatbot, when not successful (this is in 99% of cases) you are allowed to write a ticket. This is very frustrating for any developer in HW or SW - Often acquisition of smaller prosperous companies. After incorporating them into corporate processes, lay off old employees, hire newbies this business stops generating any profit and HON take hands off it.

job_title: Compliance Assurance Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I have taken on a role that was created from scratch. It has been invigorating to see the overwhelming support and offered resources to help me succeed. Despite the chaos that can come with a new position, there has never been a moment where I felt forgotten or left behind. Honeywell is a well-known brand name and working here has lived up to that. I am confident I can make a career here.
cons: There were some hoops to jump through just to begin working.

review_title: Experience changed as time went on
pros: I had some good experiences at Honeywell. Originally I worked for a company that was bought by Honeywell. Had a 26-year career including both companies and got promoted along the way.
cons: Honeywell slowly destroyed the efficiency and heart of the people working for the company, as the projects not only became global, but also the engineering teams, who had no subject matter experience. It became increasingly difficult to get anything developed to completion, and the layers of management (as well as their inexperience in the industry) were mind-boggling, while the business was stripped of actual resources to do the work. In the end, someone 4 levels up was looking at a map and a spreadsheet and closing offices, having no idea who was actually valuable or working on critical projects. All this while stating how important employees and customers were to the business.

review_title: Onboarded to become a Future Shaper
pros: -Interview Process: Usually Candidate is expected to perform best to get job in general but to my surprise Honeywell also convinced me that this is the right job. -Great Co-Workers and lot of opportunity for professional development. -Work life balance is 10/10 My Observation as a new: This organization is a home , many employees are here from longtime and eventually retire , which means we are treated as a company asset where success and growth is beneficial to both parties
cons: Experience may be different based on organization location .

review_title: Honeywell: A Diverse and Innovative Company with Room for Improvement in Company Culture and Communication
pros: Honeywell is a large and established company with a diverse range of products and services across various industries. The company has a reputation for innovation and technological advancement. Honeywell has a global presence and a strong brand recognition. The company has a commitment to sustainability and corporate responsibility.
cons: Some employees have reported a bureaucratic and slow-moving culture, which can make it difficult to implement changes or new ideas. There have been reports of a lack of work-life balance for certain positions. Some employees have reported a lack of communication and collaboration between different divisions and departments.

review_title: That suspicious feeling is you getting RIF'd
pros: So the current CEO has been there since 2018. His ambition is to turn HON into a industrial software company. It will certainly be a challenge, as their corporate culture is that if a manufacturing company.
cons: Mostly everyone I knew there when I was at the org has left voluntarily, retired, been RIF'd or were fired. Keep in mind that I've been gone for less than 2 years. My group has pretty much turned over 90% since 2019. Most of the presidents in the company have also turned over since 2019. The CEO has instilled a Jack Welch, top down, butts in seats, corporate compliance culture. If this sounds like your cup of tea, by all means, go right ahead.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Atlanta, GA
pros: good pay, benefits, perks. WFH 2 days each week.
cons: Management is not great. The majority of the team/org is offshore and we have lots of dependencies on them, early meeting times can result from this. The responsibilities of my job haven't been made clear, it's sort of been doing whatever task my manager has randomly attached me to, and each task involves completely different technology and skills, to which I haven't really been given much guidance.

review_title: I had a great manager - and that makes all the difference in the world!
pros: The benefits were great, pay was on-market for my role.
cons: Constant change is the hallmark of most industries today. You have to stay on your toes and pay attention to the small changes - as they can quickly lead to big changes. Honeywell is no exception. Every product / service has a life cycle and your role is generally tied to that lifecycle. Before coming onboard - make sure you are in an area of NPI (New Product Introduction) rather than a product the might be sunset in the next year or two.

pros: I worked at Honeywell for 2 years and had an excellent experience. The company has a high standard of work and is committed to providing the best solutions for their customers. I was impressed with the supportive culture and the opportunities for development. I would highly recommend Honeywell to anyone looking for a fulfilling and rewarding career. The company is a great place to work, and I'm grateful for the experience I had there.
cons: One of the biggest challenges was the workload. At times, the workload could be overwhelming, and it was difficult to maintain a healthy work-life balance.

review_title: The Ups and Downs up Honeywell
job_title: Assembly and Test Tech II in Tempe, AZ
pros: The list of pros contains the following: -Great Crew to work with -Plenty of advancement opportunities -Great benefits -Knowledgeable people to help guide you -Good HR Team
cons: The list of cons contains: -Slow Response Times from time to time -Pay being messed up when switching from contract to Permanent -The failure to plan ahead forcing mandatory overtime on employees making a work life balance impossible

job_title: Program Controls Specialist III in Torrance, CA

cons: Top Executive's pander to CEO requirements to fulfill investor dividen expectations and push teams to absurd amounts of work. No clear direction, no one know what we are competing with ( Efficiency? Innovation? Responsiveness? we pursue everything and get nowhere)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great crew to work with, was laid back when I started, most departments have flex time, quality over quantity, shuts down week after Christmas and your paid, safe working environment, cafe on site and plenty of vending machines, large parking lots
cons: Management doesn't care, your just a number, union is weak, can't get anything done because it's a hurry up and wait atmosphere, some departments are hard to get out of once you get in, some departments don't have flex time and there is no work around for it, engineers can be difficult to get ahold of,

review_title: A good place to learn but not earn
pros: - Interesting technology - Opportunity to try new things
cons: - Salary and career growth - Large company, hard to get credibility as a knowledgeable resource on a subject

job_title: Energy Management Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros: Every perk that kept me at the job was removed.
cons: Recent changes shifted the focus from customer service to penny-pinching. Entire teams were let go for being in the wrong location from where Honeywell wants their centers of excellence to be. Management targets good employees with unreasonable restrictions in order to meet some vague concepts of customer service levels. Judging people by their minutes logged and cases closed rather than actual customer service in roles that do not use the internal work order system. Recent management refused to learn what it is that the department they manage does and instead treated it as if everyone was replaceable by someone off the street and anyone making over minimum wage was overpaid. They were putting everyone they could on a PIP for the slightest thing - such as logging 15 minutes of unapproved overtime or getting slight negative feedback at any point from anyone.

pros: It's a reliable job. You can find your path inside the company and they help you do this by providing opportunities to change positions or teams.
cons: Even though it's such an important and recognized company, Honeywell does not really offer anything beyond the mandatory by law benefits. There's not really a community culture, only work focused. Offices are not out of the ordinary and work flexibility is declining fast.

pros: - Salary at the top of the segment - Company at forefront of products, services, processes technologies - Good career perspectives, internal promotions are common - Great attention to training, learning, updating personnel knowledges - Great colleagues from mid-mgmt to the bottom
cons: - No work/life balance - Silos mentality, even if the company would like to remove it - Heavily understaffed and nevertheless many layoffs to reduce costs - Leadership does not listen when the problem is in the details, but they ask for a great attention to details

pros: many benefits business trips work on interesting products
cons: open space changing project assignment hard carrier growth

review_title: Needs to improve approaches on people and tech development
pros: There are many senior employees that have a wealth of knowledge and experience. In general, the people that have stayed with Honeywell from pre to early 2000's still have a quality mindset and are heavily leveraged to avoid potential issues in the product development and build process.
cons: Outside of one group that focuses on research and development for generally new business opportunities, there is really no investment in technology and people development that is useful to the working engineer or new employee. R&D that is applicable to improving the competitiveness of products (new or legacy) is non existent, so the approach is generally copying old designs and tweaking the best you can. Technical development is essentially OJT, as this company does not provide much opportunity for worthwhile training or other technical skill development activities.

review_title: Lack of empathy to employees + Employee turnover + Horrible Management + Cut offs

Some employees make efforts while others do not literally anything after years. - Promotions:. they tell you, you can get promoted after a year and in fact there are some that never get promoted, and others have 2-3 promotions in about 16 months - Disfunctional management with a lot of meetings and nothing is changing. - very very slow changes. Dyfuntcional and fake HR employees, you can report laziness and missconduct from another employees and HR does not take any action. pros: - international friendly environment - flexible working hours + working hybrid 3+2 - great office complex in Prague with lot of services - intercompany growth program via Learning Hub - business development traveling - competitive salary and bonus program - some of the typical benefits including Multisport Card - lunch contribution direct part of the salary - company garage with parking places
cons: - no sick days or conditional vs pension support - limited real feedback from remoted direct managers - performance development effected by hardly reachable goals - limited how to effect the personal year goals - high rate of employee fluctuations - strict and often budget cuts and travel freezes

pros: As such a large and diversified global company, there is no shortage of interesting problems to solve and businesses to work with.
cons: There's intense pressure on senior leaders to 'execute' and get results quickly, but there is a culture of mediocrity and bureaucracy in the lower levels of the org which frequently undermines performance. Coupled with a general misunderstanding of the engineering and product talent required to build best-in-class software and what it takes to attract and retain this talent pool, it is a very frustrating place to try to execute on the high performance aspirations or convince high performers to join. The outright refusal to allow software teams to work remotely or consider equity grants/options (and even bonuses) for most employees is archaic and drives away the best employees.

job_title: Sr. Advanced Mech Design Engr  in Madurai

Office has bus facility on chargeable basis and a canteen with hygienic yet tasty food for breakfast and lunch. IT system is very effective in resolving queries. Within 15 days 4 rounds of interview had happened and I got my offer letter, the HR who involved in coordinating my interview was very efficient
cons: Its been only a month here so not much to mention other than the below point. Once joined, joining formalities were a bit long. Same documents are to be submitted to multiple places, some joining formalities were not clearly mentioned during the online induction. Understanding the internal systems for creating projects, accessing certain requirements takes time. One has to have good amount of time to manage these HR formalities, trainings as well as the actual projects.

pros: Absolutely nothing. The cost benefit of working at Honeywell is in the trenches. You may possibly get a competitive salary but you will truthfully put in more hours at this job then any you can imagine.
cons: Finance is the central guard here. Finance teams are constantly stretched thin with impossible asks and due dates. The systems at Honeywell have mapping issues so questions that come up are always seen and asked through different lenses. Upper management works you to the ground and does not take any feedback from the voice of employee scores and actions them. Attrition is through the roof so you are always on a “stretch assignment”. Training in anyway, shape or form is non existent. When people leave here, they run out of the door leaving the next person to come in the opportunity to learn from scratch. The problem is that you will get no time to do so. Please believe me when I say this…avoid this company at all costs.

pros: Massive on perks and making sure worker health is looked after. Hybrid working environment is welcoming and managers are inclusive and approachable. Everyone is very professional and kind. In one instance, depending on the calibre and quality of your work, at the end of each year Honeywell will review your performance and adjust your renum. based on your performance. Mileage is also looked after. Everyday, there is a lot of meaningful work being done at Honeywell and there is a real sense of belonging in whatever space you go into. Lots of opportunities to travel as well which is always a plus. I would recommend getting into their graduate program (especially if you're in the APAC region). You get to make real contributions and get thrown into the dep end quickly which might sound tedious, but it is how you learn best.
cons: Only downside of working at Honeywell is perhaps the time it takes for equipment. I think all employees would unanimously agree on this but they are working on fixing this. Finally, another con would be the process to get something approved. As its vertical line, this can be time consuming.

pros: Very thorough. It's clear Honeywell has an interest in and committed to engaging all employees as many was as the employees will allow. Honeywell is a large corporation with reach into many industries and there are a lot of learnings associated with that reach. Additionally, the size of the corporation drives all the on-boarding activity. The systems and people are there to support the on-boarding - from the recruiter, the on-boarding assistant, and others and while going through it. A lot of time and effort have been put into this overall process.
cons: It's too much. I understand Honeywell is multi-national and has the US government as a customer but my job responsibilities have nothing to do with exporting or chemicals. Having those modules as requirements in the first month seems excessive and just convolutes the on-boarding. Also, there are a great many links in the digital process that do not work, or seem to not work, which is probably understandable in the digital age but if that much emphasis is going to be placed on the digital world, I think it ought to work better. As a new employee, I do not know where to go to address issues like that.

review_title: Company going in the right direction
pros: It's people are its greatest asset. Industries it serves matter in the lives of so many. Very strong compensation plan, benefits are solid and vacation policy and work schedule very attractive. Good work/life balance. Huge safety culture here!

Tendency to focus on internal corporate needs vs external customer focused activity. Employees are in charge of solving a lot of their IT issues on their own, which is highly inefficient.

review_title: Lots of great people, looks after employees well, little bit cumbersome but a great place to work for
pros: Heading into my 7th year at Honeywell now, it's an interesting company for sure, though not in a bad way. My role entails something different every day, many projects, small and large, constantly evolving procedures, policies, some mind-numbingly frustrating, others, well thought out. one very important thing I find though is that people DO listen. if something's broken, you do feel empowered to be one that helps fix it. you can't say that of many Billion dollar global organisations. Unanimously though I can say that 99% of my interactions with the hundreds of internal staff globally that i've worked with has been positive. It's rare that you can genuinely reach out directly to almost anyone in the company and ask advice regarding what you're currently working on.
cons: I wish the seperate business divisions would communicate and intermix more. They push the brand 'one Honeywell' and are making fair inroads to it...it's just that we have sooo many touch points for a given project (Runway lighting, ,BMS, controls, general lighting, fire, security, life safety etc and more) , it's really hard for each separate entity to utilise common knowledge and provide solution packages to the end clients...... currently the approach seems more 'each business to it's own' BUT...I believe this is acknowledged and there are inroads to making this happen (abeit slowly) In some business divisions, it's confusing due to the wide range of products sold, often many parallel offerings doing almost the same thing! - makes a 5 minute elevator pitch quite hard....

pros: Honestly i cant really think of anything. I guess you get to work on complex problems for the future of our planet
cons:
So so many,

1. IT and HR are completely out sourced so anytime you need assistance it A-Takes forever. B-usually 90% of the time they are no help. I spent my first 2 months trying to get my computer to work after starting and just being passed around.

2. Managers are not your friends and want to work you to death. When i started this job i was told “unlimited vacation” sounds great. I was also told “we only expect 40 hours a week so if you stay longer one day feel free to leave earlier another day if you have the time”. Except none of this is true. I was told its a “Manager approved vacation only” and i shouldn't expect as a new employee to get more than 1 week vacation a year. Also i have routinely worked 50+ hour weeks with no relief or “getting to leave earlier another day” it just simply is not true.

3. Huge turnover. Basically Honeywell changed a lot of policies and people who had been in the company for years all quit. My group consist basically of all new people. Which brings me to my 4th statement.

4. ABSOLUTELY NO TRAINING OR SOPs. This absolutely blew me away. The philosophy since i started has been “figure it out” there is no documentation or SOP explaining key tasks nor is anyone around that knows how to do them because they quit.

pros: The parking is adequate most times.
cons: Seriously, if you are looking at joining this company, just don't. I have worked for 5 companies in my life, and this is by far, hands down, the worst. Don't even know where to begin. The upper management is a collusion of incompetence. Seriously, if you can make a bad decision, they can make it. The have a complete lack of concern of the employees. Literally, I don't even think it is a consideration. It is all about cutting costs, no innovation. If your company gets acquired by this beast, get out! All they will do is lay off all your support staff, off shore you jobs, make you grateful for a 1% raise, furlough you for 2 weeks every year, then lay you off. Upper engineering management is all show, not go. One dumb-assed idea, after another, all failing. They come up with a stupid strategic direction, pound you into the ground to hit a date, it doesn't sell, and it is your fault. Literally, unless you are starving, or they are hitting you at work, look elsewhere. If this company was a movie, it would the The Event Horizon, and not the good universe. I suggest you watch that movie to see where you are going if you take a job there, you'll want to sew your eyes shut.

review_title: 10 days loss of pay every year
pros: Very agile company, long term strategy changes every quarter. Awesome fire fighting experience, since that's what you do, day in and day out. You get to experiment a lot and try new theories, since there are no hard and fast rules and the management doesn't have any specific direction. Flat hierarchy, there is no concept of promotion. Over the years, you reach the ceiling of pay scale for your grade, and then you are stuck. You need to change jobs internally by following complete interview process to be considered for promotion to next grade, also it's very rare. They pay you good salary while hiring and are not shy to make better offer for deserving candidates, so negotiate well. They hire from top Schools and top companies. Highly supports diversity candidates.
cons: If your business unit is doing good, they will say, overall company is not doing good and deduct 10 days (or more) salary. And if your business unit is not doing good, they will say we are deducting 10 days salary (or more) to save jobs, and next month they will fire people. This company doesn't care about employees at all. The top management say, we are not meeting business goals, hence they are taking 10% paycut, and expect employees to take 10 days paycut, but by doing so, they push up share price and take home thick bonuses from profit sharing and the poor employees are left poorer. Everything is short term in this company, nothing is process driven, everything is person driven. Top management and leaders (even foot soldiers) get fired often. Hire and fire is core HR policy, even the HR leader accepted it himself. Severance pay is just equal to notice period payout. If you work hard and deliver results, you will get more and more work pushed at you with no appreciation. Top to down management will encourage employees to fight with each other, there is no team spirit, people are busy pulling each other's legs, to save themselves.

pros: Honeywell is a large/global company and has name recognition.
cons: I have never felt less valued as an employee than during my time with Honeywell. It is all about profits over people. The turnover in the division of Honeywell I work in is baffling. I was promoted to an interim leadership role (for no additional pay) and was told it would only be for a month or so and we are going on almost 4 months. I was setup for failure and expressed concerns to senior leadership on multiple occasions, but no serious action was taken. I have recently received an external offer and will be out the door as soon as negotiations are finalized. A direct quote from an individual who sets sales quota targets: “Well, we can’t just set someone up for success.” - if this isn’t telling of the culture, I don’t know what is.

pros: This is a good place to work if you like doing nothing.
cons:
This company hired me under false pretenses. The job was absolutely nothing like what I was led to believe it would be. The management is attempting to expand into areas that they have no business or experience in. I was hired to help with those efforts but none of my input was taken into consideration. 

This company is playing with equipment that can seriously injure or even kill employees but they are doing no real engineering or safety studies before ordering equipment. The safety culture here is horrible. The company has no values and their only goals involve making some predefined profit target. They have no idea how to motivate people to be their best or produce anything of value for society. 

They have no idea what it takes to properly engineer and fabricate process equipment. They are misrepresenting their capabilities to the US government and are milking the government for funding. You’ll spend 2 hours documenting a problem in preparation to execute a 10 minute fix. God help you if you don’t document every action taken. 9 block performance reviews - typical of any large fortune corporation. Be prepared to be under appreciated; even lambasted for over delivering. A culture of working just hard enough not to get fired as manifested by result. Accountability is scarce and everyone operates within their own self-interest.

job_title: Customer Experience Specialist in Pasadena, TX
pros:
Honeywell is a large company with many offices, but at the location where I work people here are friendly and act as a team. The company seems to generally do well in hiring good people.

Environment is a little relaxed, but people still work hard and act professional which is good. 

Resources and newsletters regarding the company is often done and easily accessible to everyone which is nice. Honeywell is involved in so much and I personally find it interesting to learn about them. They even have a nice playlist related to the Artemis launch on Spotify which I sometimes listen to while working.

A big plus is management is supportive and generally has a good attitude. My manager likes to often check in just to see how things are going.
cons:
At my location there is no onsite Human Resources or IT. If you need assistance they are contacted via phone or virtual which is just something I'm not used to.

Once onboard it can take a while to get going on work with all the setting up one has to do, however it's possible this experience may be due to my unique situation working in a new area.

review_title: Successful, wide moat company. No leadership, all toxic management.
pros: Honeywell isn't going anywhere = job security is strong. Salary + bonus well above market. Exposure to complex, global business. Lots of smart people to work with and learn from. 3 days in office, 2 remote. Quality, free, healthy snacks and lunches available. Excellent facilities and equipment.
cons: Furloughs, layoffs. Long hours (7am -7pm generally), including weekends if you want to advance. In reality, though, the stress results in work not escaping your thoughts, including your sleep (upper management says this type of all-consuming stress is a best practice; you should be obsessed with work, and anything less amounts to a lack of accountability). No true cohesive team culture - all about putting everyone else down to make yourself look better. Textbook large corporation hiding behind surface level D&I initiatives to the public, but in practice internally everyone is intentionally made to feel disposable and worthless unless business results are achieved - you have no inherent human value as a person, you're only valuable to the extent that the company achieves its quarterly goals. No room for creativity, because everyone is given an impossibly long list of non-value tasks to execute (setup for failure). Leaders do not ask fundamental questions like, "How are you doing with your workload? Do you think this is the right approach? Do you have too much on your plate? Do you need more resources?" Very little interest in you as a person. Leaders consistently dropping f bombs and generally cursing at each other, blaming/pointing fingers, condescending toward each other regardless of the amount of effort. I see little to no true "leadership" or sense of teamwork taking place. Practically speaking, it is 100% micromanagement from the top CFO down to analyst and across every team. Unnecessary rudeness is explicitly encouraged to drive results. The pay is good, but similar enough pay can be found elsewhere for significantly less stress. It isn't about the amount of work - that is expected if you are well compensated - it's the way people treat each other and the complete absence of any true leaders. Life is too short to be a part of an environment of borderline, and in some cases, outright verbal abuse, harassment, and dehumanization. Very little positivity to be found, and any attempt to voice these concerns through your manager are entirely dismissed - you are told to not let other people's emotions affect you. No hope going through human resources for fear of retaliation from management and HR exists solely to protect the employer, not the employee.

review_title: Honeywell SPS - Good people, but too heavy on process and prone to furloughs
pros: - I work for SPS. A great group of people - some of the smartest and well-intentioned folks you will ever meet. - The breadth of talent you will get a chance to work with is amazing. - Career opportunities in the organization are amazing, as is their proactive approach to talent management. - Good mentorship especially for younger employees. - 3+2 remote policy with the flexibility of which 2 days you'd like to work from home - these don't have to be the same every week. - Amazing culture and new HQ in Charlotte.
cons: - Too heavy on PowerPoint. There is a PowerPoint about how to complete a PowerPoint so you know how properly develop a PowerPoint. Joking aside - the majority of your job ends up focusing on how to prepare a PowerPoint report to support weekly, monthly or quarterly activities. This is true at all levels - from analysts to VPs. - A complete lack of onboarding. - RFIs and furloughs throughout Q3 and Q4 2022 (SPS) - Fairly average pay, especially after factoring in lost wages from multiple furloughs. - No work-life balance. You get emails and Teams messages in the evening, on weekends, and it's up to you to set the expectations of whether you are available or not. - If you are outside of the US (Europe, Asia, etc...) be prepared for late night meetings since teams are internationally dispersed, often leading to meetings outside of the normal business hours for those outside of the US. - Can be very political with a lot of CYA - Underwhelming benefits - Good 401(k) plan through Fidelity, but company matching only kicking in at the end of the year, so if you do not stay for a full calendar year you will miss out on this. Coupled with average pay and salary deductions due to furloughs you end up leaving money on the table so to speak.

It's hard to get a significant pay raise.
They often do cutting costs - if a colleague leaves, they don't always hire someone back, so you get stuck with extra work for no extra money.

pros: - Paid Overtime - Flexibility with home office (team dependent) - You can learn a lot from other colleagues and because you have to figure out almost everything on your own. - Interesting product
cons: - Toxic environment - a lot of "managers" don't know basic communication and think that if they shout or are arrogant they can get away with anything. Other simply don't communicate at all, I had periods when I didn't talk to my manager for months simply because he wasn't answering me. - No clear priorities - the company expects you to do everything in the same time and as fast as possible, without any clear reason why. I was working on products that were 20 years old and were completely outdated compared to what our competitors (or even Honeywell) was offering, but sales was insisting to keep them because of 1-2 regional customers. - Upper management talks, lower management does BAU - C-Level and Directors were constantly announcing changes or projects that never really happened - No clear guidelines or org chart - I had to go virtually around the world several times in order to find out who is responsible to paying our suppliers and then twice again in order to justify that the supplier actually needs to be paid. The finance department were one of the biggest mysteries - Escalate - the most user word in Honeywell. Everything needs to be escalated, the smallest issue, the most insignificant setback need to be escalated and after it is escalated leadership does exactly nothing to fix the issue, so you are either stuck with it or take a risk and solve it on your own and get in trouble later.

review_title: Ample Room for Growth, Poor Benefits
pros: - Amazing opportunity for growth both across many functions, businesses, and geographical regions. - Co-workers had a great breadth of talent and were enjoyable to work with. I learned much from my co-workers and many were willing to go above and beyond to meet the goals of the team. - I enjoyed the rigor that the Honeywell Operating System provided. It is is certainly not for everybody but the amount of work procedures and tribal knowledge that was documented is a breath of fresh air compared to many companies where you repeatedly scramble to figure out how to do a simple process
cons: - The amazing opportunities listed above was due to substantial churn with the organization. This churn was from employees being promoted/transferred but also those leaving the company. This resulted in many (including possibly myself) being thrust into leadership positions maybe a bit earlier than deserved or needed (very trial-by-fire atmosphere) - Multiple furloughs and reductions in force during my tenure - you are at the whim of the market and leadership - Rigid time-off and pay structures. - Extremely anti-union - this in of itself was not that significant but their treatment of a non-union shop (being so fearful of any hint of union activity) made it difficult to manage as a people-leader. We had to handle our teams so lightly and had no backing of HR to discipline where needed

review_title: Most Dyfunctional Executive Management Ever Seen
pros: Technical staff are split between excellent and committed to demotivated and demoralized.
cons: Never seen turnover as bad as at Honeywell. Easy to see why once I joined. Here's the list. Performance management is bell curved, so you are required to have non-performers. This antiquated idea is a demotivator and causes knowledge hording, team discord. Ambiguous company slogans, such as "Think Big", are used as performance metrics. Slogans are not performance metrics - they often cite overlapping , unmeasurable, skills. Funding is often frozen for aspects of a program - so R&D is unable to work on a program even when they are at work! When these freezes happen, you would expect milestones to move, right? Nope. You know how perf reviews are never supposed to be a surprise. Forget that notion. The same HR organization that runs the bell curved reviews is also responsible for engineering integrity. So if you raise engineering integrity issues, you WILL get a bad review. FYI - Honeywell makes aerospace parts, like engines and landing gear. Program war room meetings use VP level execs to intimidate working level employees: "When can that be done?", "Why was that milestone missed?" from VP to junior employees. Estimates from working level employees rarely account for overhead, rework and side effects, that's what first and second level managers are for. Honeywell eliminated first level managers (called tier 5). Blame is pushed downwards - directors and VPs are never held accountable and are frequently changed on a program (roughly every 2 years). People are blamed over process. Many processes make doing your job difficult or impossible, for example net 120 for suppliers, but net 30 for customers. Many suppliers won't work with Honeywell, especially for the quantities R&D NPI programs need. Project managers spend more time massaging metrics than managing programs. Days to convert standard automated burnup chart from Jira into burndown chart for executive consumption (they didn't get it otherwise). Enforcing the same tool across the entire company: if it's selected for manufacturing, it must be the right tool for everyone. At one point it was proposed that Sharepoint or Oracle Agile PLM by used for software source control. I once asked a VP how the finance department knew that our engineering estimate for a new product was 20% too high. He said they did comparitive analysis (!). The product didn't exist anywhere else, no other company was building it, and the last program we had that had tried to outsource it had failed (>$100M). We were estimating less than the last failure cost and it was still too much, according to finance. I found out later that all programs are undercut by finance by 20%, and usually run over the original estimate, so most engineering department were adding 25% to their costs to adjust.

job_title: Lead Chemical Engineer in Houston, TX
pros: Honeywell presents you with a very good working environment, competitive compensation/salary and a world of opportunities to make impact in your role. A place for quick career growth and the more experienced staff here are always happy to provide guidance. The hybrid work style adopted at Honeywell is a great plus for me .
cons:
1. Medical insurance deduction is too high> This is deducted per pay check (twice a month).
2. The biweekly pay is difficult to understand for a particular month.
3. Too many trainings (virtual self trainings) to do + very long onboarding tasks to complete. These trainings can take 3-6 months to complete with good understanding.

pros: My work background is pretty diverse: Military, Government Contractor, Start-up, and now Private Sector. This is how Honeywell ranks in comparison to those: Healthcare is good, it is categorized as an HDHP, but from the other places I worked, the Deductible and Out-Of-Pocket-Maximums are actually more in-line with other PPOs than HDHPs. The coverage for medicines and other stuff is better than most PPOs from other providers (this is coming from someone who has experience with family members that have chronic health issues). Work Environment: Very laid back, though this is likely dependent on your direct manager, my manager is awesome. Though dress code and stuff seems to be relaxed. I've seen people dressed up all the way to t-shirt and jeans. If you are in doubt on your first day, then go with some slacks and a polo. Hours: This depends on the job, but Honeywell is a global organization so you may work with people in different timezones. I have an early meeting typically, but management accurately adjusts expectations on end of day and arrival at the office. In-Office/Hybrid/Remote: I work in a "hybrid" role, and it is pretty awesome. I go into the office 3 days a week and work from home 2 days a week (though I typically work in a coffee shop on those days). This helps greatly because I live about 45 minutes away, so I don't have to commute every day. Either way, my manager is awesome and understanding of my time, as well as everyone I have come into contact with. The office is awesome IMO, has a cafeteria and is a nice quiet environment. If you enjoy your job and you are a hard worker, you will likely have 0 problems with this. 401K Benefits: Good, though the match only happens lump sum at the end of the year, so something to keep in mind if you are not planning on sticking around. Time-Off: I came from a "Startup" with an "unlimited" time off policy, which sadly just means you fall behind if you take time off, from what I have seen at Honeywell so far (at least by my manager), they legit make you feel comfortable with requesting time off. My manager has already told me multiple times, "Just let me know if you need some time off". The first day I started I let them know that I needed to a day off in like two months to go to a wedding and they asked if I needed more than just a day, which is the sign of a good manager! Either way, as with a lot of jobs, a lot of it depends on your manager. I would recommend that during your interviews, ensure you mesh well with your direct manager. A little advice, never think you are being interviewed for a job, always go into an interview with the primary purpose of you interviewing the job. If you are good at your job, you likely don't have an issue with getting one; use this to your advantage. The second I met with my manager, I knew we meshed pretty well as we had a similar background. I then met with their manager and a few other higher ups, and they all had a technical background and seemed very understanding. I look forwards to my future years with the company!
cons: I really can't think of any yet. I'll make sure to update this if I do.

Other issue with management is that they think they own their employees life. Its trend in this company to force people to work for long hours and on weekend. And some employees take pride in that.

review_title: Do not Join Honeywell HBT / HBS / BMS
pros:
1. Good direct managers, but unfortunately all are controlled by SG higher management by fear, and he will not be leaving anytime soon.

2. I really cannot think of any apart from the standard benefits (annual leaves, medical claims) that almost every company is offering, if not more.
cons:
I am a current employee from the dept of HBS/HBT, working on BMS/Fire system. OP from Labour Day'21 mentioned alot of facts.

Higher management "forced" everyone to sign a "voluntary unpaid leave e-form". Something what I have never imagined would happened in a MNC. Why want to implement the forced "voluntary unpaid leave e-form"? Highly likely because he already knew it was against the SG law to forced employees to take unpaid leaves, and that form was meant to protect himself in case someone whistleblow and MOM checks. And yet he still went ahead with it. Called it voluntary but said that a list of names of who signed/have no signed will be sent to himself. Why these actions if it is meant to be voluntary??

Maybe desperate to cut cost too for Covid-19, but as someone receiving a high pay/month, using this kind of method just meant he does not have the capabilities to come up with other solutions and unfit to be in that position. Paid highly to solve the issue but chose a solution that goes against the law.

Labour Day'21 has mentioned alot but not everything. It is just the tip of the iceberg. Not sure about other dept but if u join as a engineer (regardless of title name), you will be wasting your time doing mindless stuff out of your jobscope and learning nothing ! Eg: Go to customer office to collect payment cheque, deliver back to office and end up with no time to do other work, only to be criticized for not managing time properly.

Honeywell squeeze engineers dry and engineers does everything. Admin, sales, finance, budgeting, etc.

review_title: We get things done. We only get things done.
pros:
- Good learning opportunity. Exposure to projects of different natures.

- Supportive first-line managers. The managers work with the engineers to get things done. The managers are in general very capable, and are armed with the necessary skills and knowledge.

- Supportive colleagues. There's a good culture of colleagues helping each other. Most of the time, initiatives were taken to reach out to colleagues in trouble.

- Plenty of capable and dedicated engineers.

- Pay is above the market rate (but for a reason...)
cons:
- We were always in a rush to get things out. In a way, the short time span for products/fixes to be released to the market is good for the business, but it's not healthy from the engineering standpoint. We were not given enough time to research extensively and think things through.

- Workload could be heavy, to the point that personal time was sacrificed. 

- There was also an unbalanced allocation of workload. Capable engineers were loaded more heavily.

- The engineers were working on all sorts of different projects, as long as they were related to their fields. Specialisation was not emphasised, and this might result in they becoming 'generalists' rather than 'specialists'. This is limiting the engineers' growth and the quality of their work.

review_title: Questionable Leadership in HR Admin Manila Hub
pros: High basic salary but other than that the benefits package is not even at par with the current benefits package that the other competitors are offering
cons:
Questionable leadership skills of the Leadership team in Manila Hub. Poor recruitment skills that resulted to unfit people being put in different roles, heavily influenced by politics since people tends to recruit their colleagues from previous company, unfair and demotivating recognition practices without clear basis. Inconsistency is also a factor since rules only applied to some people and not for all. No employee handbook existing but they will implement rules whenever needed without clear understanding from the employees side.The contract that you signed tends to change from time to time, Example- You signed up to follow Philippine Holidays but you will be asked to report on PH holidays anyway. Benefits package is also very low compared to other Shared Services in the Philippines. They do not have HMO. SL is not convertible.

They try to stop people by leaving by means of blindly promoting anyone they can’t afford to loose even if they are not capable for the job.

review_title: Highest Paid CEO and Stellar Earnings at the expense of Employees
pros:
- A good place to acquire Aerospace product knowledge for fresh graduates 
- Emphasis on Lean and Six Sigma has been effective in making the site produce more with less.
cons:
- Repeatedly impose pay freeze and furloughs to make the earnings look good despite the company not making any losses. Rank and file employees feel the pinch with pay cuts while the senior management in Phoenix and Morristown enjoy the fruits of higher value of their stock options. Rewarding senior management not for adding value but for a zero-sum game where the company wins and the employee loses
- Extremely short sighted and can’t see beyond meeting the sales and shipment target of the month. No willingness to invest in new machines because they depreciate fast and is a drag on earnings. The plant is forced to squeeze whatever juice remaining of the old equipments which are less efficient
- Paltry employee benefits. All benefits removed due to cost reductions were not reinstated when the good times return
- No career planning for rank and file employees. Almost zero chance of organic promotion.
- Lean and Six Sigma focus means extra work for employees without headcount increase

job_title: Solutions Architect in Bukit Batok New Town,
pros:
To contribute in supply chain workflow solutions. 
Bring innovations in inbound to outbound workflow processes.
Increase accuracy and productivity in operations.
At least 50% cost savings in labour.
cons:
Need to manage reporting managers and external partners and expected to fill all gaps.
Lacks the opportunity to manage lateral partners as the reporting manager is too micro managing and wants detail level of work in progress.
Too many team meeting i.e. In one week, meet at least 2-3 times for work progress update.
Repetitive timesheet broken down into must do list, need to do list and nice to do list. Absolute redundant activity as all these tasks listed will be tracked as to do, like it or not.
Absolute indicator again of micro management by the reporting manager.

review_title: Big corporation with centralized Top-Down decision approach
job_title: Sourcing Manager in Offenbach am Main
pros: - Really good Salary (but I had to "convince" the company quite thoroughly) - Actual average salaries are between O.K. and good, depends on your approach in initial salary negotiations. - Very nice colleagues
cons: - Decisions are taken in the US - US applies a unified approach in decision making and does not care about local specifics - Very bureaucratic, static processes - Defined requirements appear sometimes to be from another world (US centric) - It was frsustrating to do the job, sometimes - Nobody actually has anything to decide locally, all job functions are depending of other job functions which leads to a collective frustration. - The most employees seem to be waiting for either their pension, their golden parachute or enough time to pass to be ready to look for the next job.

job_title: Advanced Electrical Design Engineer in Brno
pros: - Relatively high salary in the area - Well-equipped labs, and high-tech development environment - Daily contact with English-speaking colleagues - Time-to-time travel opportunities - International environment - I would say it is good for graduates
cons: - No clear vision from management for a particular business - They often let you work on some project which is later canceled - Strong feeling of useless work - Really strong bureaucracy and overprocessing for everything - You wait for ages for a clear decision approval etc. - Lots of corporate bu***t emails, meetings, reports, etc. (no time for work) - Long-term employees are often burnt out and resigned (including me after 10+ years) - Terrible IT infrastructure. They block a lot of things (including web pages that are not on the whitelist). When you need support, you can barely contact any person directly. First you need to try to solve via chatbot, when not successful (this is in 99% of cases) you are allowed to write a ticket. This is very frustrating for any developer in HW or SW - Often acquisition of smaller prosperous companies. After incorporating them into corporate processes, lay off old employees, hire newbies this business stops generating any profit and HON take hands off it.

job_title: Compliance Assurance Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I have taken on a role that was created from scratch. It has been invigorating to see the overwhelming support and offered resources to help me succeed. Despite the chaos that can come with a new position, there has never been a moment where I felt forgotten or left behind. Honeywell is a well-known brand name and working here has lived up to that. I am confident I can make a career here.
cons: There were some hoops to jump through just to begin working.

review_title: Experience changed as time went on
pros: I had some good experiences at Honeywell. Originally I worked for a company that was bought by Honeywell. Had a 26-year career including both companies and got promoted along the way.
cons: Honeywell slowly destroyed the efficiency and heart of the people working for the company, as the projects not only became global, but also the engineering teams, who had no subject matter experience. It became increasingly difficult to get anything developed to completion, and the layers of management (as well as their inexperience in the industry) were mind-boggling, while the business was stripped of actual resources to do the work. In the end, someone 4 levels up was looking at a map and a spreadsheet and closing offices, having no idea who was actually valuable or working on critical projects. All this while stating how important employees and customers were to the business.

job_title: Chemical Engineer I in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: You will be a part of field assignments in the FOS department. The work is 8 - 12 hours per shift, depending on the technology. It is fun though since it involves interaction with many international professionals. The field life is good in a different way since it involves exposure to different cultures, experiences and real time engineering applications.
cons: It's a bit stressful and not great work-life balance. Involves staying away from family, in case you are a vegetarian, it becomes more challenging to manage food.

pros: Pay was competitive and my coworkers were friendly/helped when they could
cons: Felt very unsupported by management and felt my desire to learn was impeded. My experience was very different to what was advertised during hiring by an employee who didn't even work in the same country, felt mislead when I discovered what my actual day-to-day role would be.

review_title: Honeywell: A Diverse and Innovative Company with Room for Improvement in Company Culture and Communication
pros: Honeywell is a large and established company with a diverse range of products and services across various industries. The company has a reputation for innovation and technological advancement. Honeywell has a global presence and a strong brand recognition. The company has a commitment to sustainability and corporate responsibility.
cons: Some employees have reported a bureaucratic and slow-moving culture, which can make it difficult to implement changes or new ideas. There have been reports of a lack of work-life balance for certain positions. Some employees have reported a lack of communication and collaboration between different divisions and departments.

job_title: Lead Customer Experience Specialist in Katowice
pros: The prestige of the brand but…
cons: Starting from HR and managers, they are fake. They make advertising that you will be a future shaper but unfortunately you will destroy your career path working here. I didn’t know it about the existence of this website but if you have the opportunity of reading this review take your time and tell me them your concerns of the employees and you will have this fake answer that we are taking about. Negative ambient and some of your colleagues seems are mercenaries for 5000 zl and prepare to be fired in any moment.

review_title: That suspicious feeling is you getting RIF'd
pros: So the current CEO has been there since 2018. His ambition is to turn HON into a industrial software company. It will certainly be a challenge, as their corporate culture is that if a manufacturing company.
cons: Mostly everyone I knew there when I was at the org has left voluntarily, retired, been RIF'd or were fired. Keep in mind that I've been gone for less than 2 years. My group has pretty much turned over 90% since 2019. Most of the presidents in the company have also turned over since 2019. The CEO has instilled a Jack Welch, top down, butts in seats, corporate compliance culture. If this sounds like your cup of tea, by all means, go right ahead.

review_title: Unprofessional, toxic, You do not want to work in Finance at Honeywell, please trust me.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Morris Plains, NJ
pros: They’re none. Any job in Finance can offer learning opportunities similar to Honeywell. With much less abuse, and people who are willing to help unlike here. If anything , be strong which they don’t want you to be, learn, put the experience on your resume and apply to the next higher position ASAP. Most places will see you worked at Honeywell as a sign of being through warfare and in the trenches. In the interview process at a new company, highlight that you were in very difficult working conditions, which Honeywell will give anybody. They try to play it as the next big thing, when it isn’t. For instance even on the way out you have to fill out confidentiality waivers, as if you’re going to be stealing some magic formula from them on how to build air conditioning or heaters. Give me a break.
cons: Management does not care when your family member dies, doesn’t care when have special occasions to attend critical to life, doesn’t care that you’re ill, or even having a baby. Interpersonal relationships here are lacking and terrible. Most relationships are only manufactured on the fact of “this place is terrible and let’s complain about it.” Get used to incredibly nasty management to the point of using foul and unprofessional language in meetings, hiding behind a computer screen as most are out of shape with zero hobbies, have a badge of honor stapled onto their suits. Many individuals do not encourage collaboration, rather let’s just harass people on teams until the wee-hours of the night. Critical management in key positions is so unprofessional as to not even call people by their names. Hello, this is basic 101 how to be a professional in corp America. You will be dejected. The constant abuse from management beating you up, abusing you non stop while they go on week hiatuses for reasons you’ll never understand. Over time even worse it will come into your personal and family relationships. Abuse, the best and only word to describe this place. During my time here I struggled greatly in so many aspects mentally. Days I would finish the day and question how I’d be able to continue just into the next day. It’s not where you want to work, trust me. Literally in my time I have counted over 35 individuals who have left the company. Yes, 35. Not making this up. I would say 50% of those 35 are critical mass in leading and directing key initiatives in the company. If director level individuals leave after a mere 4-5 weeks, you have to ask yourself what the hell is wrong here? Yes 4-5 weeks! The turnover rate is above 35%! Management will convince you you are learning so much (you’re not, you just think you are because you work at Honeywell and the name is supposed to mean something).. You have people higher up on the company that when they turn the camera on, never seen a smile on their face ever, look so tired and miserable, sometimes I even wonder how they maintain a family life. Many key management folks are completely miserable and it shows. Nasty, toxic, and cursing out others IN meetings! Nobody deserves to speak to people like their peons, just cause where you sit at a company. Disgusting. The work life balance is insane, sometimes even comical at times. You will be ridiculed, brainwashed when you want to spend July 4th with your family - you have to be on! Reporting on fabrication of numbers takes precedence! Half the time you’re left asking yourself why the hell am I even doing it this way? You’ll find management will want you to scew numbers, fabricate results, drop budgets down by like millions of dollars out of nowhere to make certain ratios look pretty (I mean this is insane).. the ethical conduct in this place is a 0/5. Management plays a game that they’re so busy, have no time to spend, meanwhile go out of office for weeks out of nowhere. Nobody seems to understand how to treat people in this place. There is no kindness. No true care for people. Back stabbing and giving bad reviews of other colleagues is pretty common. You will be talked about behind your back by the higher-ups if you aren’t a brainwashed, overweight individual selling yourself to this sweat shop / meat grinder. You are just a number and get used to being a peon. It’s a terrible place to work. I’ve literally had people ask me how did you take this time off during seriously important times of my life, only for them to not even bat an eye and take off weeks for vacation months later! Insane. HR knows they got a problem but only seem to care about literally killing people to get in the office. You will be on surveillance otherwise. Meanwhile many of these jobs can be done in the confines of your own home. Expectations and goals are completely insane. You will not be able to keep up with the expectations they place on you. I promise you. Because every year they come up with other stuff to pull out their behinds to show people : “ we’re Honeywell and we’re cut throat.” This place drives people to the ground, there is no knowledge sharing when people leave. No processes around transferring that knowledge to anybody. Then they complain when people leave, and even text and call them after they leave the company to understand key processes because they never even made the time to understand while they were there!!! Basics of how to do business fail here. How to operate in professional way they haven’t a clue. Just a bureaucratic, political, weak culture that stems into all elements.

review_title: The Ups and Downs up Honeywell
job_title: Assembly and Test Tech II in Tempe, AZ
pros: The list of pros contains the following: -Great Crew to work with -Plenty of advancement opportunities -Great benefits -Knowledgeable people to help guide you -Good HR Team
cons: The list of cons contains: -Slow Response Times from time to time -Pay being messed up when switching from contract to Permanent -The failure to plan ahead forcing mandatory overtime on employees making a work life balance impossible

review_title: I had a great manager - and that makes all the difference in the world!
pros: The benefits were great, pay was on-market for my role.
cons: Constant change is the hallmark of most industries today. You have to stay on your toes and pay attention to the small changes - as they can quickly lead to big changes. Honeywell is no exception. Every product / service has a life cycle and your role is generally tied to that lifecycle. Before coming onboard - make sure you are in an area of NPI (New Product Introduction) rather than a product the might be sunset in the next year or two.

pros: I worked at Honeywell for 2 years and had an excellent experience. The company has a high standard of work and is committed to providing the best solutions for their customers. I was impressed with the supportive culture and the opportunities for development. I would highly recommend Honeywell to anyone looking for a fulfilling and rewarding career. The company is a great place to work, and I'm grateful for the experience I had there.
cons: One of the biggest challenges was the workload. At times, the workload could be overwhelming, and it was difficult to maintain a healthy work-life balance.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Atlanta, GA
pros: good pay, benefits, perks. WFH 2 days each week.
cons: Management is not great. The majority of the team/org is offshore and we have lots of dependencies on them, early meeting times can result from this. The responsibilities of my job haven't been made clear, it's sort of been doing whatever task my manager has randomly attached me to, and each task involves completely different technology and skills, to which I haven't really been given much guidance.

review_title: Great experience and comp but not worth it.
pros: Great compensation and benefits.. great learning experience
cons: High stress, personal time off isn’t valued. You are seen as “a committed leader” if you put Honeywell first. Absolutely no worklife balance.

job_title: Field Service Engineer in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros: The policies are spot on when talking about diversity, inclusion and biases. They are very detailed and they teach you how to act based on circumstances. The fact that they have a training programs is what is needed in every company.
cons: Takes a long time for the devices that are ordered to get from USA to Europe.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great crew to work with, was laid back when I started, most departments have flex time, quality over quantity, shuts down week after Christmas and your paid, safe working environment, cafe on site and plenty of vending machines, large parking lots
cons: Management doesn't care, your just a number, union is weak, can't get anything done because it's a hurry up and wait atmosphere, some departments are hard to get out of once you get in, some departments don't have flex time and there is no work around for it, engineers can be difficult to get ahold of,

review_title: Honeywell is a great place to work

cons: you need good domain knowledge to work in R&D companies like Honeywell so it will take good number of years to get such knowledge. so you need a long term commitment.

job_title: Program Controls Specialist III in Torrance, CA
pros: Very well payed in comparison to larger and more competitive corporations.
cons: Top Executive's pander to CEO requirements to fulfill investor dividen expectations and push teams to absurd amounts of work. No clear direction, no one know what we are competing with ( Efficiency? Innovation? Responsiveness? we pursue everything and get nowhere)

job_title: Energy Management Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros: Every perk that kept me at the job was removed.
cons: Recent changes shifted the focus from customer service to penny-pinching. Entire teams were let go for being in the wrong location from where Honeywell wants their centers of excellence to be. Management targets good employees with unreasonable restrictions in order to meet some vague concepts of customer service levels. Judging people by their minutes logged and cases closed rather than actual customer service in roles that do not use the internal work order system. Recent management refused to learn what it is that the department they manage does and instead treated it as if everyone was replaceable by someone off the street and anyone making over minimum wage was overpaid. They were putting everyone they could on a PIP for the slightest thing - such as logging 15 minutes of unapproved overtime or getting slight negative feedback at any point from anyone.

review_title: Needs to improve approaches on people and tech development
pros: There are many senior employees that have a wealth of knowledge and experience. In general, the people that have stayed with Honeywell from pre to early 2000's still have a quality mindset and are heavily leveraged to avoid potential issues in the product development and build process.
cons: Outside of one group that focuses on research and development for generally new business opportunities, there is really no investment in technology and people development that is useful to the working engineer or new employee. R&D that is applicable to improving the competitiveness of products (new or legacy) is non existent, so the approach is generally copying old designs and tweaking the best you can. Technical development is essentially OJT, as this company does not provide much opportunity for worthwhile training or other technical skill development activities.

pros: As such a large and diversified global company, there is no shortage of interesting problems to solve and businesses to work with.
cons: There's intense pressure on senior leaders to 'execute' and get results quickly, but there is a culture of mediocrity and bureaucracy in the lower levels of the org which frequently undermines performance. Coupled with a general misunderstanding of the engineering and product talent required to build best-in-class software and what it takes to attract and retain this talent pool, it is a very frustrating place to try to execute on the high performance aspirations or convince high performers to join. The outright refusal to allow software teams to work remotely or consider equity grants/options (and even bonuses) for most employees is archaic and drives away the best employees.

pros: Absolutely nothing. The cost benefit of working at Honeywell is in the trenches. You may possibly get a competitive salary but you will truthfully put in more hours at this job then any you can imagine.
cons: Finance is the central guard here. Finance teams are constantly stretched thin with impossible asks and due dates. The systems at Honeywell have mapping issues so questions that come up are always seen and asked through different lenses. Upper management works you to the ground and does not take any feedback from the voice of employee scores and actions them. Attrition is through the roof so you are always on a “stretch assignment”. Training in anyway, shape or form is non existent. When people leave here, they run out of the door leaving the next person to come in the opportunity to learn from scratch. The problem is that you will get no time to do so. Please believe me when I say this…avoid this company at all costs.

pros: Massive on perks and making sure worker health is looked after. Hybrid working environment is welcoming and managers are inclusive and approachable. Everyone is very professional and kind. In one instance, depending on the calibre and quality of your work, at the end of each year Honeywell will review your performance and adjust your renum. based on your performance. Mileage is also looked after. Everyday, there is a lot of meaningful work being done at Honeywell and there is a real sense of belonging in whatever space you go into. Lots of opportunities to travel as well which is always a plus. I would recommend getting into their graduate program (especially if you're in the APAC region). You get to make real contributions and get thrown into the dep end quickly which might sound tedious, but it is how you learn best.
cons: Only downside of working at Honeywell is perhaps the time it takes for equipment. I think all employees would unanimously agree on this but they are working on fixing this. Finally, another con would be the process to get something approved. As its vertical line, this can be time consuming.

pros: Very thorough. It's clear Honeywell has an interest in and committed to engaging all employees as many was as the employees will allow. Additionally, the size of the corporation drives all the on-boarding activity. The systems and people are there to support the on-boarding - from the recruiter, the on-boarding assistant, and others and while going through it. A lot of time and effort have been put into this overall process.
cons: It's too much. I understand Honeywell is multi-national and has the US government as a customer but my job responsibilities have nothing to do with exporting or chemicals. Having those modules as requirements in the first month seems excessive and just convolutes the on-boarding. Also, there are a great many links in the digital process that do not work, or seem to not work, which is probably understandable in the digital age but if that much emphasis is going to be placed on the digital world, I think it ought to work better. review_title: Negotiate all you can on the way in…
pros: Honeywell UOP- Industry leading product lines. Competitive starting pay.
cons: For performance reviews Honeywell utilizes Performance Differentiation also known as “vitality curve" but frequently called "rank and yank," this was developed by Jack Welch and championed by GE for decades. This was dropped by GE 10 years ago because it was determined that a rankings-based mentality and a "survival of the fittest" work environment, where employees feel pressured to outperform their colleagues in order to avoid being at the bottom of the list. This can lead to stress, tension, and disharmony in the workplace. As a further result, a majority of Honeywell’s management falls into 2 categories; Marionette boss: They are mere puppets who follow orders of the higher boss. They tend to exude no loyalty to their employees and never stands up for them. Taskmaster boss: Their sole focus is on the bottom line. Continuously drilling employees is a sure way that makes them unhappy at work. Micromanagement suffocates, demoralizes and kills creativity.
